passages.text: With this note we transfer coverage of the stocks listed below to Kate McCutcheon. We maintain our rating, target price and estimates for each stock.

Stocks to be transferred include: BHP Group (BHP.AX), Bluescope Steel (BSL.AX), Boss Energy (BOE.AX), Champion Iron (CIA.AX), Deterra Royalties (DRR.AX), Fortescue Ltd (FMG.AX), Iluka Resources (ILU.AX), Lynas Rare Earths (LYC.AX), Paladin Energy (PDN.AX), Rio Tinto (RIO.AX), South32 (S32.AX), Whitehaven Coal (WHC.AX).

We rate BHP Neutral on valuation grounds. BHP continues to simplify its core business and an exit from Petroleum should focus the company on existing large- scale assets in iron ore, copper and metallurgical coal with potash an emerging long- life, large- scale asset. In FY26, BHP trades on a \(9.8x P / C F\) EV/EBITDA of 7.0x and dividend yield of \(3.7\%\) (52% payout ratio) with benchmark iron ore at US \(93 / t\)

Our target price is a rounded \(A\) 43.0 based on DCF and multiples valuation. Our DCF valuation uses a \(7.5\%\) real, after- tax, unlevered discount rate and a beta of 1.1. Our long- term equilibrium commodity prices and other key assumptions are based on our commodities team's latest forecasts. Our multiples analysis focuses on \(6.5x EV / EBITDA\) multiples (in- line with peer average) based on FY27 forecasts. We derive our 12- month target price from a 50:50 weighting of div adj. NPV and earnings multiples analysis.

The key downside risks to our projected earnings, cash flows and target price relate to weaker- than- expected commodity prices/economic growth and currency fluctuations. Operating risk in BHP is lower than for smaller metals and mining companies with fewer operations. Likewise, upside risk to projected earnings relate principally to higher- than- expected commodity prices/economic growth. If the impact on the company from any of these factors proves to be greater/less than we anticipate, the stock will likely deviate from our target price.

We are Neutral- rated on valuation grounds. We see that Australia's steel consumption has moderated this year and expect residential detached construction (one- third of BSL's domestic steel demand) will remain at capacity for, perhaps, multiple years. Moreover, rising interest rates and declining house prices present a possible cyclical headwind. We note that BSL's significantly restructured operations in the past four years have made it more resilient to market downturns. We also acknowledge BSL's strong balance sheet that can support higher dividends/capital management.

Our rounded target price of \(23.0\) is derived by rounding an equal- weighted DCF, SOTP, and PE relative valuation. Our DCF of \(23.85\) is based on WACC of \(7.5\%\) (beta of 1.2, equity risk premium of \(7.5\%\) , risk- free rate of \(2.0\%\) ). Our PE relative valuation of \(20.90\) based on an \(10.0x PE\) multiple applied to BSL's 2027E EPS. For our SOTP valuation of \(25.0\) consider an EBITDA
multiple of 5.0x applied to 2027E segment EBITDA. Our valuation multiples are in line with the industrials peer group.

BSL's businesses are cyclical with certain exposure to a volatile commodity prices and emerging markets. Key risks to our earnings and valuation include: (1) weakness or slowing in construction activity with Australia, New Zealand, North America and countries in the emerging markets: China, India, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Vietnam; (2) declines in finished steel prices or significant sustained increases in key input costs (Iron ore, scrap steel, hard coking coal); (3) Unfavorable currency translation impact; (4) Competition from imports and substitute products; and (5) Large restructuring charges and asset write- downs.

If the impact on the company from any of these factors proves to be greater than we anticipate, the stock will likely have difficulty achieving our financial and price targets. Conversely, if any of these factors proves to have less of an effect than we anticipate, the stock could outperform our target.

We are Buy rated on valuation grounds. BOE is a play on rising uranium (U308) demand due to the projected global supply deficit and nuclear energy's role in the global energy transition and artificial intelligence. We believe another leg- up in U308 pricing is inevitable with strong consolidation around US \(65 - 75 / lb\) despite contracting activity being below replacement levels. The Russian nuclear fuel export ban and potential continuations of problems with mine development in Kazakhstan should also keep prices elevated. We forecast U308 prices to average US \(115 / lb\) in 2027.

We generate a rounded price target of \(2.70 using a 100\%\) weighted DCF. We assume a WACC of \(7.5\%\) , LT real U308 price of US \(80 / lb\) , LT AUDUSD of \(0.75x\) and production forecasts in line with the latest guidance. We also give additional value to extra resources at Honeymoon (Gould's Dam & Jason deposit) as these new mineralisation target areas will form the basis for additional growth at Honeymoon.

This stock is High Risk based upon our quantitative model but assigning a High Risk rating is not supported by other qualitative factors such as market capitalisation & owning two producing mining assets, and so a High Risk rating has not been applied.
We see the following downside risks to achieving our target price:
- A drop in uranium spot or term prices would decrease revenue.- Strengthening AUD against USD (given constant USD U308 price).- Delays or problems in ramping up production at Honeymoon or Alta Mesa
could defer revenue generation.
- The inability to achieve mining production rates, uranium grade in mineral resource, recovery and dilution assumptions.
- Rising operating and SIB expenditure from inflationary pressures.
Upside risks that would cause the share price to exceed our target price:
- Significant exposure to rising uranium prices.
- Weakening AUD against USD (given constant USD U3O8 price).
- Exploration success at Honeymoon's satellite deposits and large tenement holding.
- Optimising of processing facilitates, or lower-than-expected production costs could improve profitability.
- Further collaboration with other industry players to develop greater technologies and exploration success.

We are Buy- rated on CIA. The company has achieved significant production growth with the Bloom Lake Phase II expansion ramp- up and is now upgrading 7.5mtpa to \(69\%\) DRPF product. In contrast, most iron ore peers have had limited production growth prospects.

Using a 50/50 combination of 4.5x FY27E EV/EBITDA (March year- end, post Phase II expansion) and dividend- adjusted DCF, we generate a rounded price target of A\(6.20. We assume a WACC of 7.50%, a long- term P62 iron ore price of US\)85/dmt, a long- term P65 premium of 18% and a P69 premium of 39% over the P62 benchmark, implying a long- term P65 and P69 iron ore price of US\)100/dmt and US\)118/dmt, proceeds from the conversion of warrants of \(80m, and some optionality value for Kami project.

This stock is High Risk based upon our quantitative model, but we do not believe assigning a High Risk rating is supported by other qualitative factors - CIA is already a producer and exporter of iron concentrate from its Bloom Lake operation in Canada, and its Phase II expansion capex will be largely self- funded from free cash flow, which is elevated in the near term due to high C\$ iron ore prices. As such, a High Risk rating has not been applied.

We see the following as upside risks to achieving our forecasts and target price for CIA: 1) Canadian dollar P62 iron ore price upside; 2) a higher premium for the P65 Canadian dollar iron ore price; 3) lower- than- expected capex requirements for Phase II expansion; 4) faster Phase II production ramp- up
than expected; and 5) mine life extensions beyond the current \(\sim 20\) - year mine life.

We see the following as downside risks to achieving our forecasts and target price for CIA: 1) Canadian dollar P62 iron ore price downside; 2) a smaller premium for the P65 Canadian dollar iron ore price; 3) higher- than- expected capex requirements for Phase II expansion; 4) slower Phase II production ramp- up than expected; and 5) a shorter- than- expected mine life due to the inability to convert resources which are not already also into reserves.

We are Buy rated on DRR on valuation grounds. We forecast that iron ore production in the MAC Royalty Area will grow from 59.8Mwmt in FY19 to 150Mwmt in FY26, as South Flank ramps up. We forecast DRR will deliver peak EBIT in FY25, driven by our forecast for iron ore prices. DRR remains attractive long- term with our new iron ore price- deck using a P62 iron ore price forecast of US \(85 / \mathrm{dmt}\) (CFR).

Our 12- month rounded target price for DRR is A \(4.40. We value DRR on a 100% div adjusted NPV of A\) 4.43. We assume a WACC of 4.5%, a long- term P62 iron ore price of US \(85 / \mathrm{dmt}\) (CFR), US \(19,000 / \mathrm{t}\) long- term lithium carbonate price, and a 70% risk weighting for the Thacker Pass project.

We see the following as upside risks to achieving our forecasts and target price for DRR: 1) Mine life extensions at the MAC Royalty Area beyond our current expectations for operations to continue out to 2060; 2) Australian dollar iron ore price upside; 3) Faster- than- expected production expansions at the MAC Royalty Area and/or production expansions beyond the 150Mwmt annual production rate we forecast by FY26; 4) Value- accretive organic growth outside of the existing production growth forecasts at the MAC Royalty Area; 5) Value- accretive inorganic growth; and 6) A lower risk- free rate.

We see the following as downside risks to achieving our forecasts and target price for DRR: 1) Shorter- than- expected mine life at the MAC Royalty Area; 2) Australian dollar iron ore price downside; 3) Slower- than- expected production expansions at the MAC Royalty Area and/or production expansions unable to achieve the 150Mwmt annual production rate we forecast by FY26; and 4) A higher risk- free rate.

We rate FMG Neutral on valuation grounds. FMG has rapidly de- leveraged the balance sheet and greatly reduced the company's risk profile, which we expect to continue. Despite concerns around a growth slowdown in China, we believe there will be continued heavier reliance on domestic investment for GDP growth with steel heavy infrastructure and automotive sectors remaining key pillars for China's economic growth.

We derive our rounded target price of \(A\) 19.0 from a 50:50 blend of 6.5x FY27E EV/EBITDA and NPV less expected dividends to be paid. Our FMG valuation is based on DCF analysis using a 7.5% real, after- tax, unlevered discount rate using a beta of 1.1, long- term iron ore price forecast of US \(85 / \text{dmt}\) and a LT A \(\) /US\(exchange rate of 75\) .

We see the following key risks to our target price: FMG is exposed to a single commodity with two mines, leaving it highly exposed to operational and commissioning delays. FMG is highly leveraged to the iron ore price and a lower A \(\) is beneficial to earnings. If the impact on the company from any of these factors proves to be greater than we anticipate, the stock will likely have difficulty achieving our financial and price targets. Conversely, if any of these factors proves to have less of an effect than we anticipate, the stock could materially outperform our target price.

We rate Iluka Neutral/High Risk on valuation grounds. Key upside case for ILU is further price increases for the titanium dioxide feedstocks as pigments plant maximise production through higher grade. Recent bullish sentiment in rare earths have seen the shares rally. The commitment to a - \(\) 1.8bn\(rare earths refinery creates valuation uncertainty given current cost pressures on WA metals and mining projects but should also transform the earnings base of ILU to be\) >50\%\(rare earths when the refinery is fully ramped up.

Our rounded target price for Iluka of \(A\) 5.30 is based on 100% of dividend adjusted NPV. Our NPV valuation is based on a DCF analysis using a 7.7% real discount rate. Long- term equilibrium commodity prices used are US \(\) 1,000/t\(for rutile, US\) \ \(1,400/t\) for zircon, and A \(\) /US\(of 0.75. We also use a 90% risk weighting on our Rare Earths Refinery valuation with a LT US\) 90/kg NdPr price.

We rate ILU High Risk to reflect the significant uncertainties due to the dependency on the refinery providing value which would need a substantial improvement in rare earth pricing and/or the creation of an ex- China rare earths market.
Key risks to achieving our projected earnings, cash flows and target price

relate to weaker/stronger- than- expected commodity prices/economic growth. The commitment to a rare earths refinery creates valuation uncertainty given current cost pressures on WA metals and mining projects. Positive risk factors are further price increases for the titanium dioxide feedstocks, increased operational efficiency from simplifying its operations and depreciation of the A\$. Favorable or adverse movements of these risk factors may cause ILU's share price to deviate from our target price.

We back Lynas' decade- long experience in rare earth refining and expect LYC to lift capacity to - 12ktpa NdPr oxide by FY28 (from 5.88kt in FY22). LYC is the largest REO supplier outside of China and we believe end users will place increasing value on ex- China sourced supply. LYC is a play on rare earth supply chain security concerns, accelerating EV penetration and the global energy transition. The share price is highly correlated to NdPr prices. However, we are Sell rated based on valuation grounds and highlight the weak medium- term demand outlook creating a poor pricing environment for NdPr Oxide. Incentivised to keep its global rare earths dominance, we expect China to use its excess capacity to keep rare earth prices well below US\(100kg.

Using a \(50\%\) DCF valuation and \(50\%\) capital raise offer price we generate a rounded target price of A\(9.50. We assume a WACC of 7.50%, LT real NdPr price of US\)90/kg (VAT excl.), LT 0.75 AUDUSD, full ramp up of - 12ktpa target starting in FY28 and a mine life until 2055.
We see the following downside risks to achieving our target price:

- Kalgoorlie C&L failing to ramp up.- Operational issues causing a slower-than-expected ramp up (or failure to reach) the 12ktpa NdPr target.- Higher operating costs than forecasted.- The NdPr price falling below our expectations due to: (1) Coordinate pricing by Chinese SOEs to protect market share and/or larger than expected refined quota increases; (2) Substitution risks from new technology and/or other rare earths; (3) Slower-than-expected global energy transition.

- Faster-than-expected ramp up and/or growth options beyond the 12ktpa NdPr target.- Lower operating costs than forecasted.- The NdPr price rising above our expectations due to: (1) Slower-than-expected refined and recycled supply; (2) Faster-than-expected EV penetration; (3) Faster-than-expected global energy transition.

We are Buy- rated on valuation grounds. PDN is a play on rising uranium demand due to the projected global supply deficit and nuclear energy's role in the global energy transition. PDN's Langer Heinrich Mine represents one of a few of uranium projects globally that is ready to come on- stream in the early stages of the emerging uranium bull market. We believe another leg- up in U308 pricing is inevitable with strong consolidation likely around US \(65 - 75 / lb\) despite contracting activity being below replacement levels. The Russian nuclear fuel export ban and potential continuations of problems with mine development in Kazakhstan should renew upward momentum in U308 prices. We forecast average prices US \(115 / lb\) in 2027 as balances continue to look tight.

Using a \(100\%\) DCF valuation and 1.2x NAV multiple, we generate a rounded price target of A \(\) 9.90\(. We assume a WACC of 7.50%, LT real U308 price of US\) \ \(80 / lb\) , and a mine plan in- line with PDN's 2024 LHM Technical Report (hitting 6mlb U308 pa run rate by end of CY25). We value the PLS project in- line with is 2023 Technical Report. We also value PDN's Australian and Canadian resource base on EV/Resource comps.

This stock is High Risk based upon our quantitative model, but assigning a High Risk rating is not supported by other qualitative factors such as market capitalisation and low risk re- start mine plan, and so a High Risk rating has not been applied.
We see the following downside risks to achieving our TP:

- Our bearish uranium price scenario assuming a severe economic slowdown in DM countries, uninterrupted flow of Russian supplies, and increasing capabilities in the Western hemisphere for fuel production.
- New nuclear reactor technologies allowing for greater utilisation of uranium and improved recyclability of waste products (MOX and RepU).
- Spot AUD strengthening against USD.
- Delayed commencement of production beyond Q1-CY2024 and/or failure to ramp up to 6mlb p.a U308.
- Higher-than-expected operating costs and SIB capex levels.
- Political risk in Namibia/Australia/Canada on uranium mining.
Upside risks that would cause the share price to exceed our target price:
- Our bullish uranium price scenario assuming a sudden ban on all Russian-origin uranium and continuous problems with global uranium production.
- Accelerated nuclear reactor buildouts (including SMRs) around the globe and/or utilities/governments reversing decisions to shutdown nuclear plants.
- Spot USD strengthening against AUD.
- Operational efficiencies and variable inputs costs achieving a lower-than-expected operating costs and SIB capex levels.
- Re-rating of Australian resources.

We rate RIO Neutral on valuation grounds. The shares have retraced in 2022 on market fears around China growth and falling commodity prices but have since rebounded from higher iron ore prices and improving operational performance. We expect elevated copper prices to provide earnings support in CY25/26. Higher energy costs are a benefit for RIO's aluminium business versus peers.

We calculate our one- year target of \(A\) 119/sh using a 50:50 combination of NPV and earnings multiples analysis less expected dividends to be paid. Our multiples- based valuation uses 6.0x EV/EBITDA multiples for FY27E, in- line with the peer group average. Our core NPV valuation is based on DCF analysis using a 7.5% real, after- tax, unlevered discount rate, long- term \(A\) /US exchange rate of 75, and iron ore price forecast of US \(85/t\) (dry CFR).

Key risks to our projected earnings, cash flows and target price relate to weaker- than- expected commodity prices/economic growth and currency fluctuations. Country risk is a consideration with about \(20\%\) of operations by NPV in Africa and South America. Operating risk in RIO is lower than for smaller metals and mining companies with fewer operations.

If the impact on the company from any of these factors proves to be greater than we anticipate, the stock will likely have difficulty achieving our target price. However, should they be less than anticipated, the stock could trade above our target price.

We rate S32 Neutral on valuation grounds. S32 is doing a good job of reducing costs and we see robust free cash flow generation beyond FY24 that creates further cash return potential for the company. We believe S32 would also benefit from the supply- side reforms in China that support aluminum
and high- quality steel- making raw materials.

We derive our 12- month target price at \(A\) 3.20 for South32 from a 50:50 weighting of dividend adjusted NPV (with a \(\sim 20\%\) group discount given an uncertain macro backdrop) and earnings multiples analysis. Our core NPV valuation is based on a DCF analysis using a \(7.5\%\) real, after- tax, unlevered discount rate and a beta of 1.1. Our multiples- based valuation focuses on a \(3.0x\) EV/EBITDA multiple applied to our FY27 forecasts. We use a lower multiple than peer group average to reflect the lower mine life of \(\sim 10\) years.
We see the following key risks to the achievement of our target price:

South32's earnings are linked to prices in world commodity markets, which have been subject to substantial volatility recently. These prices are in turn influenced by economic, new government regulations and geopolitical factors, notably the Chinese economy. A slowdown in Chinese economic growth would therefore adversely impact prices and consequently South32's revenue. South32's diversification across aluminium, alumina, manganese, nickel, silver and coal has the potential to mitigate this risk.

The majority of South32's revenues are in US dollars but with mines and processing plants in a number of countries, the influence of other currencies such as the A\\$, Brazilian real, South African rand on the operating cost base is equally significant. Fluctuations in these currencies can therefore heavily impact South32's earnings.

If the impact on the company from any of these factors proves to be greater than we anticipate, the stock will likely have difficulty achieving our target price. However, should they be less than anticipated, the stock could trade above our target price.

We rate Whitehaven Coal (WHC) Neutral on valuation grounds. The ramp- up of Maules Creek to a potential \(+16\mathrm{m}\) tpa ROM, combined with incremental growth from the Vickery development, is expected to drive mid- term volume growth for WHC with Winchester South a longer- dated option.

We derive our rounded target price of \(A\) 7.10 from a 50:50 weighting of discounted dividend adjusted NPV and multiples analysis. Our WHC base valuation (NPV) is based on DCF analysis using a \(7.5\%\) real, after- tax, unlevered discount rate. Our multiples analysis focuses on \(3.5x\) EV/EBITDA multiples based on FY27 forecasts.

Generally, the key risks surrounding WHC and our target price are as follows: - Commodity price: Coal prices have become more volatile over the past five years as the historically bulk- traded market has moved to a more terminal market approach. - Port: Access to port remains a risk in an infrastructure- constrained world. WHC's ownership in NCIG mitigates this risk. If the impact on the company from any of these factors proves to be greater than we anticipate, the stock will likely have difficulty achieving our target price. However, should they be less than anticipated, the stock could trade above our target price.

Guide to Citi Research Fundamental Research Investment Ratings:

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

Investment Ratings: Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment

rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of \(15\%\) or more or \(25\%\) or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "—" and "—" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re-establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short-term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in reaction to one or more specific near- term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds \(15\%\) against the direction of the call (unless over- ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer- term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings- distribution- disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution- disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share- price movement will not materialize as expected.
